item.title: Israel vows war 'not over' after pulling troops out of southern Gaza
item.dc:creator: Yuliya Talmazan and Reuters and Yael Factor
item.description: The Israeli military says it has reduced the number of ground troops in the southern Gaza Strip following the conclusion of its monthslong operation in the city of Khan Younis, raising questions about the future of its offensive in the enclave amid pressure from the U.S. to reduce the war’s humanitarian toll.

media:content.media:text: An Israeli soldier moves atop a tank near the Israeli-Gaza border
media:content.media:description: An Israeli soldier moves atop a tank near the Israeli-Gaza border on April 4, 2024.

item.title: Haitian police seize hijacked cargo ship after 5-hour shootout
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press and Michelle Garcia
item.description: Haiti’s National Police agency says that it has recovered a hijacked cargo ship laden with rice following a gunbattle with gangs that lasted more than five hours.

media:content.media:text: A National Police officer patrols an intersection in Port-au-Prince, Haiti
media:content.media:description: A National Police officer patrols an intersection in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, on Jan. 26.

item.title: Yellen says U.S. plans to 'underscore' need for China to shift policy
item.dc:creator: Evelyn Cheng, CNBC
item.description: Future talks between the U.S. and China will focus on Beijing’s need to shift its policy on industry and the economy, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said.

media:content.media:text: Image: CHINA-US-DIPLOMACY
media:content.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen in Beijing on Monday.

item.title: Yemen's Houthis say they targeted Western ships
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: CAIRO — Houthi forces in Yemen said on Sunday they had launched rockets and drones at British, U.S. and Israeli ships, the latest in a campaign of attacks on shipping in support of Palestinians in the Gaza war.

media:content.media:text: Yemen Coast Guard Houthi
media:content.media:description: Members of the Yemeni Coast Guard affiliated with the Houthi group patrol waters near the Red Sea port city of Hodeida in on Jan. 4.

item.title: Turning point? After deadly strike on aid convoy, Democrats push Biden to put conditions on military help for Israel
item.dc:creator: Dan De Luce and Julie Tsirkin and Frank Thorp V and Megan Lebowitz
item.description: The Israeli airstrike that killed seven World Central Kitchen aid workers has outraged Democrats in Congress and could be a turning point in how Washington sees Israel’s war against Hamas.

media:content.media:text: People gather around the carcass of a car used by aid group World Central Kitchen.
media:content.media:description: People gather around the carcass of a car used by aid group World Central Kitchen that was hit by an Israeli strike in the central Gaza Strip on April 2, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Peter Welch and Jose Andres
media:content.media:description: Sen. Peter Welch, D-Vt., left, walks with chef Jose Andres, founder of World Central Kitchen, at the Capitol on March 14, after a briefing with senators on how to get food aid into Gaza.

media:content.media:text: The passports of World Central Kitchen workers.
media:content.media:description: The passports of World Central Kitchen workers who were killed in the Israeli airstrikes.

media:content.media:text: Gregory Meeks
media:content.media:description: Rep. Gregory Meeks, D-N.Y., at roundtable with family members of individuals being held hostage by Hamas at the U.S. Capitol on November 29, 2023.

item.title: Aid agencies say the Israeli military has been attacking their workers for months
item.dc:creator: Gabe Joselow and Aurora Almendral and Doha Madani and Dan De Luce and Caroline Radnofsky and Matthew Mulligan
item.description: 224 aid workers have been killed since the start of the war, as the death of WCK aid workers highlight the failure of the Israeli military to protect aid workers in line with international humanitarian law.

media:content.media:text: A man displays blood-stained British, Polish, and Australian passports after an Israeli airstrike in Deir al-Balah, Gaza, on April 1, 2024, killed seven World Central Kitchen workers.
media:content.media:description: A man displays blood-stained British, Polish, and Australian passports after an Israeli airstrike in Deir al-Balah, Gaza, on April 1, 2024, killed seven World Central Kitchen workers.

media:content.media:text: Palestinians walking in front of the closed headquarters of the World Central Kitchen on April 3, 2024, west of Nuseirat, central Gaza.
media:content.media:description: Two women walk past the closed headquarters of the World Central Kitchen in central Gaza.

media:content.media:text: Palestinians look a vehicle in Deir Al-Balah, Gaza, on April 2, 2024, the day after it was destroyed by an Israeli airstrike that killed World Central Kitchen workers.
media:content.media:description: Palestinians look at a vehicle Monday in Deir Al-Balah, Gaza, the day after it was destroyed by an Israeli airstrike that killed World Central Kitchen workers.

item.title: Class destroyed: A look at what has become of Gaza's revered universities
item.dc:creator: Chantal Da Silva and Yasmine Salam and Matthew Mulligan and Bianca Britton
item.description: Built over decades, Gaza’s universities embodied the ambitions of young Palestinians. In weeks, the Israeli military destroyed them.

item.title: She secretly educated herself to escape Afghanistan. Now, she's working to help women still there
item.dc:creator: Maya Eaglin
item.description: Sola Mahfouz stopped going to school in 2007 when she was an 11-year-old living in Afghanistan.

media:content.media:text: A portrait of Sola Mahfouz
media:content.media:description: Sola Mahfouz.

media:content.media:credit: Courtesy Sola Mahfouz and Malaina Kapoor
media:content.media:text: Sola Mahfouz and Malaina Kapour laugh while speaking.
media:content.media:description: Sola Mahfouz, left, and Malaina Kapoor.

media:content.media:credit: Courtesy Sola Mahfouz and Malaina Kapour

media:content.media:description: Sola Mahfouz and Malaina Kapour.

item.title: Meet the families who've taken children as young as 2 to Everest Base Camp
item.dc:creator: Aria Bendix
item.description: A handful of families have taken children as young as 2 years old to Mount Everest Base Camp in recent years. Three of them describe the experience.

media:content.media:text: Hazel Matulis at Everest Base Camp in 2022.
media:content.media:description: Hazel Matulis at Everest Base Camp in 2022.

media:content.media:text: Dimple Laddha took her daughter, Arishka, last year when Arishka was just 6 years old.
media:content.media:description: Dimple Laddha took her daughter, Arishka, to Everest Base Camp last year at 6 years old.

media:content.media:text: Chris and Cindy Matulis with their kids at Everest Base Camp in 2022.
media:content.media:description: Chris and Cindy Matulis with their kids at Everest Base Camp in 2022.

media:content.media:text: Dimple Laddha took her daughter, Arishka, last year when Arishka was just 6 years old.
media:content.media:description: Dimple Laddha and Arishka last year.

media:content.media:text: The Matulis kids at Everest Base Camp in 2022.
media:content.media:description: The Matulis kids at Everest Base Camp in 2022.

item.title: Looking for leads, not love: Job seekers in China turn Tinder into a networking tool
item.dc:creator: Larissa Gao and Helen Chen
item.description: Young people in China facing an increasingly tough labor market are turning to an unlikely place for help in their job searches: Tinder.

media:content.media:text: Photo Illustration: A man's Tinder profile reads "Looking for Full-tim employment"
media:content.media:description: Some young people in China see Tinder as a way to find potential job leads.

media:content.media:text: China Youth Unemployment
media:content.media:description: University students at a job fair in Wuhan, China, in March.

item.title: British man runs nearly 10,000 miles along the length of Africa
item.description: It took less than a year for a British man to run the length of Africa, almost 10,000 miles. NBC’s Matt Bradley shares the moment he crossed the finish line.

media:content.media:title: British man runs nearly 10,000 miles along the length of Africa
media:content.media:description: It took less than a year for a British man to run the length of Africa, almost 10,000 miles. NBC’s Matt Bradley shares the moment he crossed the finish line.

item.title: Tensions rising between Mexico and Ecuador over embassy incident
item.description: Police in Quito, Ecuador, stormed the Mexican embassy and arrested Ecuador’s former vice president. Now Mexico has severed diplomatic ties with Ecuador, saying the raid violated international law.

media:content.media:title: Tensions rising between Mexico and Ecuador over embassy incident
media:content.media:description: Police in Quito, Ecuador, stormed the Mexican embassy and arrested Ecuador’s former vice president. Now Mexico has severed diplomatic ties with Ecuador, saying the raid violated international law.

item.title: Netanyahu announces date has been set for Rafah ground offensive
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said a date has been set for Israeli forces to carry out an offensive in the southern Gaza city of Rafah. Such an offensive is opposed by the Biden Administration, which is increasing pressure on Israel to negotiate a deal for a cease-fire and the release of hostages held by Hamas for six months. NBC News' Hala Gorani reports.

media:content.media:title: Netanyahu announces date has been set for Rafah ground offensive
media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said a date has been set for Israeli forces to carry out an offensive in the southern Gaza city of Rafah. Such an offensive is opposed by the Biden Administration, which is increasing pressure on Israel to negotiate a deal for a cease-fire and the release of hostages held by Hamas for six months. NBC News' Hala Gorani reports.

item.title: At least 94 killed in Mozambique boat accident, officials say
item.description: Cellphone video showed dozens of bodies on a beach in Nampula province, Mozambique, after a small fishing boat ferrying more than 100 people capsized.

media:content.media:title: At least 94 killed in Mozambique boat accident, officials say
media:content.media:description: Cellphone video showed dozens of bodies on a beach in Nampula province, Mozambique, after a small fishing boat ferrying more than 100 people capsized.

item.title: 'Hey Jude' is out, 'Anti-Hero' is just right: Chechnya bans songs deemed too fast or too slow
item.dc:creator: Yuliya Talmazan
item.description: Taylor Swift, Beyoncé and even The Beatles’ back catalog could be off playlists in Chechnya after the Russian republic instituted limits on musical tempo.

media:content.media:text: Ramzan Kadyrov dances.
media:content.media:description: Ramzan Kadyrov with a Chechen girl dressed in a national costume in Grozny, Russia in 2007.

item.title: A typically French disruption threatens a key part of the Olympics as medal-makers go on strike
item.dc:creator: Alexander Smith and Nancy Ing and The Associated Press
item.description: Paris 2024 Olympics medals are the subject of French strike action after workers at the country's national mint protested over pay ahead of the summer Games.

media:content.media:text: Paris 2024 Olympic medals.
media:content.media:description: Paris 2024 Olympic medals in Saint-Denis, France, on Feb. 8, 2024.

item.title: China's Xi meets with Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov in show of support against Western democracies
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Chinese leader Xi Jinping met with Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov on Tuesday in a sign of mutual support and shared opposition to Western democracies amid Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine.

media:content.media:text: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, left, shakes hands with Chinese State Councilor and Foreign Minister Wang Yi.
media:content.media:description: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, left, shakes hands with Chinese State Councilor and Foreign Minister Wang Yi on April 24, 2018 in Beijing, China.

item.title: Trial opens in Thailand for the son of Spanish actors over the killing of a Colombian surgeon
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Thailand’s court began a trial Tuesday of the son of Spanish actors accused of killing and dismembering a Colombian surgeon on a popular tourist island.

media:content.media:text: Daniel Sancho Bronchalo
media:content.media:description: A Thai police officer escorts Spanish Daniel Sancho Bronchalo in southern Thailand on Aug. 7, 2023.

item.title: Swiss women score a landmark climate win in a court decision that could ripple across Europe
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Europe’s highest human rights court ruled Tuesday that its member nations have an obligation to protect their citizens from the ill effects of climate change, but still threw out a high-profile case brought by six Portuguese youngsters aimed at forcing countries to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

media:content.media:text: People demonstrate outside the European Court of Human Rights.
media:content.media:description: People demonstrate outside the European Court of Human Rights on April 9, 2024 in Strasbourg, France.

media:content.media:text: Greta Thunberg
media:content.media:description: Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg, left, joins youths outside the European Court of Human Rights on April 9, 2024 in Strasbourg, France.

media:content.media:text: President of the European Court of Human Rights Síofra O'Leary
media:content.media:description: President of the European Court of Human Rights Síofra O'Leary, center, on April 9, 2024 in Strasbourg, France.

item.title: Anger boils over as Russians stage rare protest after record floods
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: At least 100 Russians asked for help from President Vladimir Putin on Monday in a city struck by the worst flooding ever recorded, chanting “shame on you” at local officials who they said had done too little to help their plight.

media:content.media:text: Rescuers evacuate residents from the flooded part of the southern tip of the Ural Mountains, Russia.
media:content.media:description: Rescuers evacuate residents from the flooded part of the southern tip of the Ural Mountains, Russia on April 8, 2024.

item.title: Culinary diplomacy: The internet is obsessed with what Janet Yellen eats in China
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Since eating mushrooms that can have psychedelic effects in Beijing, Janet Yellen has united Americans and Chinese in wanting to know what she will eat next.

media:content.media:text: Janet Yellen
media:content.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, center, in Beijing last year.

item.title: As total eclipse nears Mazatlán, banda groups stand their ground amid noise complaints
item.dc:creator: Jaylinn Herrera
item.description: As the beach city of Mazatlán, Mexico became the focus of international attention due to the eclipse's path, local banda music bands fought to remain part of the iconic beach landscape — and its sounds.

media:content.media:text: Views Of Mexico's Pearl Of The Pacific
media:content.media:description: A banda group plays near the beach at sunset in Mazatlán, Mexico, in 2015.

item.title: Vatican blasts gender-affirming surgery, surrogacy and gender theory as violations of human dignity
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: The Vatican on Monday declared gender-affirming surgery and surrogacy as grave violations of human dignity, putting them on par with abortion and euthanasia as practices that reject God’s plan for human life.

media:content.media:text: The prefect of the Vatican's Dicastery for the Doctrine of the Faith, Cardinal Victor Manuel Fernandez, presents the declaration 'Dignitas Infinita'
media:content.media:description: Cardinal Victor Manuel Fernandez presents the declaration "Dignitas Infinita"' ("Infinite Dignity") at a news conference at the Vatican on Monday.

item.title: In Mexico, 19 feral cats can officially roam the presidential palace fur-ever
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Nineteen feral cats living in the grounds of the National Palace have made history after the López Obrador government declared them “living fixed assets,” and will be taken care of as long as they live.

media:content.media:text: Ollin in one of the National Palace courtyards, in Mexico City
media:content.media:description: Ollin at the National Palace in Mexico City on March 4.

media:content.media:text: Coco nibbles on a blade of grass in a National Palace courtyard, in Mexico City
media:content.media:description: Coco nibbles on a blade of grass at the National Palace in Mexico City on March 4.

media:content.media:text: Veterinarian Jesus Arias greets Ollin at the National Palace courtyard, in Mexico City
media:content.media:description: Veterinarian Jesus Arias greets Ollin at the National Palace in Mexico City on March 4.

item.title: Premier League club Everton docked two more points over finances, deepening relegation threat
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Everton was docked two more points on Monday for its latest breach of the Premier League’s financial rules, plunging the team back toward the relegation zone with seven games remaining.

media:content.media:text: Everton's Dominic Calvert-Lewin celebrates during a soccer match between Newcastle United and Everton in Newcastle, England
media:content.media:description: Everton's Dominic Calvert-Lewin celebrates during a match against Newcastle United in Newcastle, England, on Tuesday.
